Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Experience in Computational Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a CISE Research Experience for Undergraduates site focused on computational science at the University of Houston. Each year, ten students are to be recruited from institutions that offer limited research opportunities. The program emphasizes steering non-traditional students into research, reinforcing their interest in computer science, and providing professional development opportunities for the students. Research in these areas of national importance is overseen by an interdisciplinary team of faculty mentors and is reinforced through site visits to cutting-edge research laboratories in the local area.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in strong research basis and the expertise of the faculty. The projects are in major current research areas that are of interest to the community at large and that have clear practical applications.

The broader impacts of the project include providing a quality research experience to undergraduate students, particularly students from underrepresented groups and from institutions with limited research environments. Thus this project has the potential to produce new computer science graduate students and faculty members and to advance discovery and understanding while promoting learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU award has provided 37 undergraduate students (seven more than what we proposed) the opportunity to experience research and the understanding of academic/research career paths in Computer Science.  It also provided these students with valuable information regarding their decisions about whether or not to attend graduate school. The program achieved its goals of providing students with a high-quality research program that gave them valuable information about conducting research and encouraging them to consider seriously graduates studies in computer science or in a related area. The large majority student participants viewed the program as an academic and personal success. Furthermore, the students had a good time and clearly indicated (via the questionnaire and inter-personal communication) that they had had a productive and enjoyable summer.  As a result, our program also attracted talented undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented backgrounds to participate. Of the 37 participant over three years, 15 were from underrepresented minority (40% compare to the national norm of 12.3% based on Taulbee Survey) and 10 of them are women (27% compare to national norm of 14% based on Taulbee survey).  The results of this REU program in Computational Science clearly indicate that the program was successful in deepening the students’ knowledge of computer science and engaging them in meaningful research.
